Although I do not require sustenance, I occasionally ingest a semi-organic nutrient suspension in a silicon-based liquid medium.
Is it good?
It would be more accurate to say it is "good for me" as it lubricates my bio-functions.
It doesn't sound too appealing. What else is there?
A wide variety of items... the replicator can make anything you desire.
How am I supposed to know what I desire?
I have observed that many food selections are influenced by the mood of the person ordering...
I'm in a dreadful mood... get me something appropriate...
When Counselor Troi is in an unhappy mood, she often has something chocolate...
Chocolate...
For example, a hot fudge sundae. I cannot speak from personal experience, but I have seen it often has a profound psychological impact.
I'll have ten hot fudge sundaes.
I have never seen anyone eat ten.
I'm in a really bad mood. And since I've never eaten before, I should be very hungry.
This... is not a moment I've been looking forward to.
I heard you were drummed out of the continuum.
I prefer to look at it as a significant career change.
Just one of the boys, huh?
One of the boys with an IQ of two thousand and five.
The Captain and much of the crew are not yet convinced that he is truly human.
Is that right?
AAAH...
He's human.
This is a dangerous creature. You have no idea... how could Picard allow her to join the crew and not me...
It must be frightening... totally defenseless... after being omnipotent all those centuries...
I'm warning you... I still have friends in high places...
... terrorizing one race after another... teasing them like helpless animals... delighting at the fear of your victims...
From now on, I'll do missionary work...
That would be a very noble cause, Q.
You could learn a few things from this one.
Sure, the robot who teaches the course in humanities.
I am an android, not a robot.
I beg your pardon.
Get used to it, Q.
What?
Begging. You're a pitiful excuse for a human and the only way you're going to survive is by the charity of others.
I'm not hungry.
Captain, sensors are picking up a cloud of energetic plasma... bearing three-four-one mark two-zero... range twelve kilometers and closing...
On screen.
Energy patterns are reading as highly organized...
A lifeform?
Mister Worf, attempt to make contact...
Receiving a signal, sir... on speaker...
Computer, analysis of signal...
Signal patterns indicate intelligence. Unable to derive necessary referants to establish translation matrix.
Calamarain...
We're being hit by a field of energetic tachyons... penetrating the hull... location... deck ten... forward...
Red alert.
Increase power to shields...
Increasing power by twenty percent...
No effect...
Increasing to forty percent...
Still no effect...
Adjusting shield harmonics... Diverting power to the forward grids.
The added harmonics are blocking the tachyon field.
HELP ME. SOMEBODY HELP ME...
How the mighty have fallen.

Captain's log, supplemental. We have sustained light damage from an attack by an alien species known as the Calamarain. They apparently have a grievance with Q... no doubt one of many lifeforms that do.
The Calamarain are not very hospitable creatures. They exist as swirls of ionized gas.
What did you do to them to motivate such a vengeance?
Nothing bizarre. Nothing grotesque.
You tormented them --
A subjective term, Riker. One creature's torment, is another creature's delight. They simply have no sense of humor... a character flaw with which you can personally identify.
I say we turn him over to them.
Oh, my mistake... you do have a sense of humor... a dreadful one.
I'm serious.
Of course. You knew this would happen, didn't you?
I assure you one cannot anticipate the Calamarain, Picard... they're intelligent, yes... but undependable... very flighty...
But you have so many enemies, Q, of various shapes and sizes... certainly you must have been concerned that once you became mortal... some of them might try to look you up...
It occurred to me.
With all your chatter about "friendship", the real reason you're here is for protection, isn't it?

You're so bright, Jean-Luc. Yes, of course, you're correct. I know human beings. You are all sopping over with compassion and forgiveness. The human race can't wait to absolve almost any offense. It's an inherent weakness in the breed.
What you call weakness, some of us would call strength.
Call it what you want, Picard. I know you'll protect me even though I've tortured you now and again...
Fighting off every species you've insulted would be a full time mission. And it's not the one I signed up for.
Indeed. Human or not, I want no part of you. We will deposit you at the first starbase. Let them deal with you...
But I can be a valuable member of your team, Picard...
As though you have the faintest notion about team-work or cooperation...
I can learn. I'm human.
Then I suggest you apply to Starfleet Academy...
Don't use me as a reference.
He has provided important theoretical guidance for Geordi's analysis of the Bre'el satellite, Captain.
It seems you have an advocate, Q.
I am only stating a fact, Counselor.
Mister La Forge, your status?

I've been putting together a program to extend the forward lobe of our warp field. The field coils are not designed to envelop such a large volume. But I'm attempting to modify their alignment parameters.
Maintaining field integrity will be difficult, Geordi.
I think we can do it manually. The moon's reaching its perigee in fourteen minutes...
Mister Data, escort Q to Engineering... You will assist Mister La Forge.
Mister Worf, hail the Bre'el Four science station.
Picard really thinks I can't cut it on his starship... I can do anything his little trained minions can do.
I do not perceive that your skills are doubted, Q. I believe the captain is more concerned with your ability to interact successfully with... his "little trained minions".
Human interpersonal relationships are most complex... your experiences may not have adequately prepared you.
I don't want human interpersonal relationships. I just want to prove to Picard that I'm indispensable.
To function aboard a starship, or in any human activity, you will have to form relationships.
Why does this have to be so hard...
Of more immediate importance is your ability to work within groups...
I've never been any good in groups... it's difficult working in a group when you're omnipotent...
The tides reached ten meters on the last orbit. They are already beginning to swell again. We have a lot of frightened people down here, Captain...
Your moon has begun moving toward its perigee, Doctor... we are prepared to make our attempt...
Our population has already taken shelter... but I'm afraid no shelter will be adequate if you fail... Especially for the people on the western continent.
Whatever the results, we know you've done your best, Picard. It's appreciated.
I'll keep you advised, Doctor. Picard out.
Captain, sensors are reading increased energy output from the Calamarain...
La Forge to bridge. The moon has reached its minimum orbital distance... it's time, Captain...
We'll have to lower shields...
Proceed. Mister Worf, keep a close eye on Q's friends out there...
Understood.
Okay, everyone, here's what we're going to do...
Q, everybody already knows what they're going to do, except for you... now here's what I need...
La Forge, obviously my knowledge and experience exceed yours... by about a billion times... so if you'll just step aside gracefully...
Your experience will be most valuable to me if you can manually control the field integrity...
Don't be foolish. That's a waste of my talents...
Get to the controls or get the hell out of here...
Data, you're my liason to the bridge... I'll need you with me...
Who does he think he is to give me orders...
Geordi thinks he is in command here... and he is correct.
Engineering, holding at station keeping, range six hundred and forty meters.
Containment fields to flight tolerance.
Warp core to ninety percent.
Engage field coils. Tractor beam to stand-by. Field output... ? Field output... ?
Two-seventeen...
Impulse engines to full. Ready to engage tractor beam.
Lowering shields. Engage tractor beam.
Extending warp field forward.
Engineering, is that the forward limit?
Yes, Captain... we are unable to encompass the entire moon...
Do you recommend we proceed... ?
The two parts of the moon will have different inertial densities...
I can adjust the field symmetry to compensate...
I doubt it.
You don't know what this ship can do, Mister...
Yes, Captain... I think it still might work... increasing power to tractor beam and warp field...
And if you're wrong, the moon will crumble due to subspace stress... don't say I didn't warn...
Shut up, Q.
I will not be spoken to in this manner...
Data...
Q, I strongly advise that you return to your post.
Inertial mass of the moon has decreased to approximately two-point-five million metric tons...
It's working. We can move it. Firing impulse engines...
The moon's trajectory has moved point-three percent... point-four percent...
Emergency... shields up...
Disengage tractor beam...
Calamarain attacking...
Shields holding... tachyon field repelled...
Captain, the impact of the blast is pushing us into the upper atmosphere...
Hull temperature rising... two thousand degrees... two thousand five hundred degrees.
Moving to full impulse power... we've gotta get out of here...
Calamarain are resuming attack...
They've overpowered the shields... hull penetration... deck thirty-six... Engineering...
Geordi, can you direct any more power to the shields... ?
We need all the power we have to get out of the atmosphere, Commander.
Try activating the structural integrity field.
It's not working. Structural field harmonics on manual.
Hull temperature falling, Geordi... we're in the clear...
Diverting power to forward section. Now.
Data... Data... ?
What about me?
The charge nearly knocked out his positronic net.
What can you do for him?
We'll try to discharge and reset the motor pathways, recouple autonomic nodes...
There's overpressure in his fluidic systems, thermal shock... If he was mortal, he'd be dead.
(with a subtext of guilt) Let us not overstate matters here, Doctor... I am mortal and I survived...
The cheers are overwhelming.
You exceed your own standards of selfish preoccupation. Have you no concern for the officer who very probably saved your life?
(more hope than conviction) He's strong, he'll survive.
Osmotic pressure still negative. Maybe if we by-passed the flow regulator...
It would be helpful if everybody just got out of here now...
We'll let you know as soon as there's anything to tell you.
Geordi, the moon's trajectory... ?
All we did was buy ourselves another orbit at most... we can try again when it comes back to the perigee...
And when we drop our shields, the Calamarains go after Q again...
He's not worth it, Commander.
Come...
You're right, of course. I am extraordinarily selfish. It's served me so well in the past...
It will not serve you here.

Don't be so hard on me, Jean-Luc. You've been mortal all your life. You know all about dying. I've never given it a second thought. Or a first thought for that matter. I could have been killed. If not for Data... that one, brief delay he created, I would have been gone. No more me. And nobody would have missed me, would they?
And yet Data may have sacrificed himself for me. Why? Why would he risk his own life for mine?
That is his special nature. He has learned the lessons of humanity well...
I ask myself if I would have done the same for him. And I am forced to realize the answer is no. And I feel... I feel ashamed.

I am not your father confessor. You will not receive absolution from me, Q. You have brought nothing but pain and suffering to my crew. And to this very moment, I am not entirely convinced that this is still not your latest attempt at a bad joke.

It is a bad joke. On me. I am the joke of the universe. The king who would be man. As I learn more and more about what it is to be human, I am more and more convinced that I will never make a good one. I just don't have what it takes, Jean-Luc. Without my powers, I'm frightened of everything. I'm a coward. I'm miserable. And I don't think I can go on this way.
He's going to be all right.
We're recalibrating his language circuits... he can't talk to us yet.

There are creatures in the universe who consider you the ultimate achievement, android. No feelings, no emotions -- no pain. And yet you covet those qualities of humanity. Believe me, you are not missing anything. But if it means anything to you, Data... you are a better human than I.
Where's the Main Shuttlebay?
Main Shuttlebay is located on deck four.
Take me there...
An unscheduled shuttlecraft has just been launched.
On Main Viewer.
Opening hailing frequency.
Frequency open.
Shuttle occupant. Identify yourself.
Don't try to talk me out of it, Jean-Luc.
Q? Return to the ship at once.
I just can't get used to following orders.
Captain, the plasma cloud is moving toward the shuttle.
It's easier this way. They won't bother you after I'm gone.
Engineering, prepare to extend shields...

Please, do not fall back on your tired cliche of charging to the rescue in the nick of time... I do not wish to be rescued... My life as a human being is a dismal failure. Maybe my death can have a little dignity.
There is no dignity in suicide...
Yes, I suppose you're quite right. The death of a coward. So be it. Anyway, as a human, I'd die of boredom.
This goes against all my better judgment... Transporter Room Three, lock on to Shuttle One... beam it back to it's bay.
Aye, Captain...
Well, it's a perfectly good shuttlecraft...
Captain, unable to transport... For some reason, I can't lock on...
Worf, are you sensing any sort of interference from the Calamarain?
No, Commander, but they are continuing to move toward the shuttle.
Geordi, extend shields around Shuttle One...
Extending shields ... Commander... the shields are frozen...
Cause...
Unknown.
Lock on tractor beam...
Tractor beam is not functioning either...
What the hell is going on?
Not bad, Q. Not great. But not bad.
Sacrificing yourself for these humans... ? Do I detect a selfless act... ?
You flatter me. I'm only trying to put a quick end to a miserable existence.
What a dreadful color.
What are you doing here?
I've been keeping track of you.
Really? I always felt you were in my corner...
Actually, I was the one who got you kicked out... You're incorrigible, Q, a lost cause. I can't go to a single solar system without apologizing for you... and I'm tired of it...
I wasn't the one who misplaced the entire Deltived asteroid belt...
This is not about me. I have better places to be. But, somebody had to keep an eye on you in case you still found a way to cause trouble... even as a member of this limited species...
I hope I've kept you amused.
Barely. But these humans are rather interesting... I'm beginning to understand what you see in them. After all the things you've done, they're still intent on keeping you safe.
A genetic weakness of the race.
And they're still at it. They just tried to beam you back or whatever they call it... I stopped them...
Well then, if the Calamarain will just hurry up and finish this, we'll get you on your way...
No, I put them on hold too. There's still this matter of the selfless act...
You and I both know that the Calamarain would have eventually destroyed the Enterprise to get to you... and that's really why you left...
It was... a tiny bit selfless... wasn't it...
And there's my problem. I get back to the continuum and tell them you committed a selfless act just before the end... I'm gonna be tied up with questions and explanations for centuries...
Q, I've learned my lesson...
Remember who you're talking to here... all knowing, all seeing... Fine. You have your powers back. Try to stay out of trouble...
And they wanted to destroy me, did they?
If you think I tormented you in the past, my little friends -- wait until you see what I do with you now.
I was just seeing if you were still watching
Sir, the aliens have disappeared. And so has the shuttle.
Scan the sector...
I have, sir.
Well, I guess that's the end of Q.
Au contraire, mon capitaine... heee's back...
I have been forgiven, embraced by my brothers and sisters of the continuum... I am immortal again, omnipotent again...
Swell.
Don't fret, Riker... my good fortune is your good fortune.
I don't need your fantasy women, Q...
You've become so stolid, Commander... you weren't like this before the beard...
Very well...
But I feel like celebrating...
I don't.
All of it.
Now, at the risk of being rude...

Yes, I have once again overstayed my welcome. As a human, I was ill-equipped to thank you, Picard. But as myself, you have my everlasting gratitude. Until next time, of course. But before I go, there is a debt I must repay...
... to my professor of the humanities... I have decided my dear Data to give you something very, very special...
If your intention is to make me human, Q...
No no no no no... don't be foolish... I would never curse you by making you human... Let's just call it a going away present.
Uh, Data... Data? Why are you laughing?
I do not know. But it was a wonderful... feeling.
Bre'el Four hailing us, Captain.
On screen, Lieutenant.
Captain Picard... you've done it...
I'm sorry... ?
The moon is back in its normal orbit. How did you manage it?
I didn't. Stand by, Bre'el Four...
Let's see it, Worf...
Mister Data, your analysis...
The moon's altitude is fifty-five thousand kilometers, projected orbit is nearly circular. There is no further danger to the planet.
Good. Ensign, set a course for Station Nigala-Four. Perhaps there's a little humanity left in Q after all.
(whispered so only he can hear it) Don't bet on it, Picard.
... there's a time when you want to call a Romulan's bluff and there's a time when you don't... (beat, waiting for a response, then... ) Wouldn't you say?
Yes, well, one does not always have the luxury...
You've got to choose your time and place with them. True or false?
Whenever possible.
So, this time you were lucky.
I suppose all's well that ends well but if I had been in your shoes...
Well, it looks very nice, Mot... that should suffice...
Hold on...
...there.
I must tell you, Captain, Will Riker was in for a trim yesterday... and he agreed with me a hundred per cent...
Bridge to Captain Picard...
(hits insignia, with an edge) Yes?
Sorry to interrupt. We're receiving an emergency distress signal from the Solarion Four colony.
Uh oh, right along the Cardassian border...
Lay in a new course. I'm on my way.
I told him we never should have colonized that close to the Cardassians...
Report.
The signal ended abruptly at oh four five five... unable to raise them on subspace...
Hail them on upper and lower band frequencies, Mister Worf...
I've tried, sir. No response.
Time to the Solarion system?
Twenty-six minutes, Captain.
I understand you've been discussing alternative adversarial engagement strategies with Mot.
It would be more accurate to say he was discussing them with me... He's the best barber in Starfleet... what can you do... ?
Sir, receiving another signal from a vessel leaving orbit of Solarion Four... new frequency, low band... audio only...
Open the channel.
This is the Bajorans. We claim responsibility for the destruction of the Federation colony on Solarion Four. As long as we are without our homeland, no one will be safe in this sector.
Captain's log, stardate 45076.3. We have arrived at Lya Station Alpha with survivors from Solarion Four. Admiral Kennelly has rendezvoused to discuss the Bajoran terrorist attack.
Sorry...
Ginger tea with honey, very hot.
Ginger tea?
My Aunt Rebecca's cure for the common cold.
Common, hell... I picked this up from the Cardassian liaison last weekend. It's some damn virus they've sic'ed on me.
Did the liaison have anything to say about the attack?
It's an old story for the Cardassians. They've had terrorist problems since they annexed the Bajoran home world forty years ago.
But in forty years, the Bajorans have never attacked a Federation target...
A new militant splinter group has broken away from the Bajoran settlement camps. Leader's name is Orta. Apparently he's willing to do whatever he has to to get attention...
And our response?
We're going to give him attention. I can't tell you how good this feels on my throat...
Listen, I'm the first to say that the Bajorans deserve attention... chased off their own planet by the Cardassians, forced to wander the galaxy, settling wherever they can find room...
On many worlds we've been to, they are isolated, treated as pariahs...
The Federation has great sympathy for their cause... but they're not helping themselves with an attack like this. That's what you have to communicate to them.
That could be done through diplomatic channels, Admiral... what do you really want from us?
Find this terrorist leader, Orta... get him back "on the reservation"... any way you can.
Any way I can...
The Federation has dozens of settlements in that sector. We can't allow the violence to continue.
And what do I have to offer that might persuade him to cooperate?
Amnesty.
Admiral...
... and a promise that we will immediately begin to address this issue with the Cardassians... quietly, behind the scenes, using every legitimate means... the Bajorans have to be patient...
They have endured generations of sympathy and promises. I cannot believe this Orta will be satisfied with more of the same.
It's your job to see that he is, Jean-Luc.
Riker to Captain Picard.
Go ahead.
Captain, have you approved the transfer of a new officer to the Enterprise?
Negative...
Well, I've got one waiting to transport aboard...
... complete with orders. Ensign Ro Laren.
Ro Laren? From the Wellington?
The same one, sir. Should I tell her a mistake's been made?
Stand by, Commander.
I wrote the orders. I thought she'd be valuable to you.

Admiral... respectfully... (beat, trying to fashion a polite way of saying this) I would appreciate some consulting rights on the assignment of a new officer... especially someone with the record of Ro Laren...
She's Bajoran.
There are other Bajorans in Starfleet... assign one of them...
I've discussed this situation with her. I'm convinced she's the right one for the job...
After what happened at Garon Two, she has no business serving on any starship as far as I'm concerned... let alone the flagship, my ship...
You're taking her... it's all arranged... you have no idea how difficult it was to get her out of prison.
It's that important to you...
It's that important. To the mission.
Picard to Riker.
Go ahead.
Proceed with the transport.
Sir... ?
I'll fill you in later, Commander.
Yessir.
Admiral, I hope neither of us regrets this.
You can handle her, Captain. If anyone can.
I'll be on my way, then. Actually, you know, I think I'm feeling better.
Aunt Rebecca would be pleased.
Energize.
Ensign Ro Laren reporting as ordered, Commander.
You'll follow the Starfleet uniform code aboard this ship, Ensign.
There will be members of the crew who will not want to serve with Ensign Laren, Captain.
They'll have to learn to live with it.
I intend to demand the highest standards of performance from her.
I would expect nothing less.
It won't be for long, Will.
Come.
Yes, Ensign Laren, please have a seat...
Ensign Ro. Sir.
I beg your pardon?
The Bajoran custom has the family name first, the individual's second. I am properly addressed as Ensign Ro.
I'm sorry, I didn't...
No reason you should know. It is an old custom. Most Bajorans these days accept the distortion of their names in order to assimilate. I do not.
I wish to be candid with you, Ensign.
Please.

I am fully aware of your Starfleet record, your problems on other ships, the incident on Garon Two that led to your court martial. I feel it only fair to inform you that I am personally concerned about your presence on this most critical mission...
I don't want to be here any more than you want me to be here. Sir.
Then why did you accept this assignment?
If I may be equally candid... it's better than prison.
Better than prison. Ensign, there are officers who wait years to serve aboard this...
... being called back into Starfleet wasn't my idea...
... Nor ours...
... and I'm not exactly happy about it.
Nevertheless... ... we are going to be serving together and I think it would be wise for Commander Riker and me to clearly voice our expectations and...
Captain, I know the routine. You don't have to worry about me. We're stuck with each other. Let's get this over with as quickly as possible and we'll go our separate ways, okay?
Dismissed.
Captain's log, supplemental. We are approaching the Valo system on the outskirts of Cardassian territory, where many Bajorans have resettled.

There are dozens of Bajoran camps on the three M-class planets. I suggest we may want to begin on Valo Three, where an ad hoc leader named Jas Holza lives. The Federation has had several dealings with him...
I met Holza at a symposium a few years ago...
What can you tell us about him, Doctor?
I found him to be a very concerned leader and a good spokesman for his people... And a terrific dancer...
Really... at the reception afterwards...
At least this man has genuine experience in diplomacy...
That is not a small advantage on this mission... Very well... Mister Data, contact Holza, arrange a meeting... set a course for Valo Three.
Ensign Ro, you're familiar with this star system; take the conn...
Is there some problem, Ensign?
You're wasting your time.
Holza is nobody. He's the token Bajoran that "respectable" people... ... invite to symposiums and diplomatic soirees. But he has no real influence among my people.
Whom do you suggest we talk to, Ensign?
Don't you understand? These are desperate people. Ready to martyr themselves. They don't want to talk...
This ship is prepared to defend itself if necessary.
It will be. Don't fool yourself. This mission will end in bloodshed.
Well. Let us hope you are mistaken, Ensign. Now... perhaps you could point us in the right direction as Mister Data suggested.
I would go to the camp on the southern continent of Valo Two... find a man named Keeve Falor. He has no diplomatic experience. And he won't ask you to dance.

Captain's log, supplemental. I read about the achievements of the ancient Bajoran civilization in my fifth grade reader... they were architects and artists and builders and philosophers... when humans were not yet standing erect.
Now I see how history has rewarded them...
This used to be me.
Baleekam... Balleek... balleek!
Ro Laren, it has been a long time. We welcome your return.
Keeve Falor. Captain Jean-Luc Picard. Commander Data and Lieutenant Worf.
Thank you for meeting with us, Mister Keeve.
You honor me by the proper use of my name, Captain.
Ensign Ro has educated me.
Has she. Good. I'm pleased you still remember.
Let me show you our camp.
We are not a violent race, Captain. Just passionate about our cause. And that passion has led some to take up arms.
Do you know where we can find Orta?
I'm afraid not.
Might you be able to help us locate him?
I'm sorry. I don't wish to help you.
Don't misunderstand. I for one believe the raid on the Federation outpost was poor judgment. You are innocent bystanders, and I cannot condone violence against those who are not our enemies.
Then I don't understand why you are unwilling...
Because you are innocent bystanders.
You were innocent bystanders for decades as the Cardassians took our homes... as they violated and tortured our people in the most hideous ways imaginable... as we were forced to flee...
We were saddened by those events... but they occurred within the designated borders of the Cardassian Empire...
... and the Federation is pledged not to interfere in the internal affairs of others.
How convenient it must be for you. To turn a deaf ear to those who suffer behind a line on a map.
I'm not here to debate Federation policy. I am prepared to offer assistance...
Simply because of one terrorist attack? Then perhaps I have been wrong. We should have attacked the Federation long ago. What do you think of that, Ro?
I think you are a small man who feels a rush of power in his belly and enjoys it far too much, Keeve. Stop talking and listen.

We have had our own problems with the Cardassians... now that there is a treaty, we are in a position to help. Your people have been forced to resettle all over the quadrant. We can make a legitimate case with the Cardassians that this is no longer an isolated problem. We will work diplomatically on your behalf... but first the terrorist attacks must end.
We live in different universes, you and I. Yours is about diplomacy, politics, strategy. Mine is about blankets. If we were to exchange places for a night, you would better understand.
Mister Data -- see to it that our replicators provide blankets for every man, woman and child here before nightfall.
Yessir.
Mister Worf, you will determine if these people have any other emergency needs and provide whatever we can...
Aye, sir.
Return to your ship. I will contact you when I have any information that might be of assistance. Ensign.
You were helpful.
The blankets were helpful... nothing I said mattered.
In an age when their technology should be able to feed and clothe all of them... that they should have to live like this...
I couldn't. And I wouldn't. That's one reason why I ran away. They are lost... defeated...
I will never be.
Captain's log, stardate 45077.8. Keeve Falor has kept his promise and directed us toward the third moon of Valo One... where we will meet tomorrow with the terrorist leader, Orta.
Do you mind if we join you?
Yes.
... I'll tell you one thing... if I find myself on an away team with Ensign Ro... I'll never turn my back on her...
The captain obviously thought she'd be valuable on this mission.
This was orders. Had to be. She doesn't belong here. Doesn't belong in the uniform if you ask me.
Really.
Really.
Sounds like someone I'd like to meet.
Am I disturbing you?
Yes.
Good. You look like someone who wants to be disturbed.
I'd rather be alone.
No you wouldn't.
I beg your pardon... ?
If you wanted to be alone, you would've stayed in your quarters. Only reason to come here is to be around people.
There's always the view...
You've been looking at your drink all night. How's the view?
Who are you?
Guinan. I keep the bar. I listen.
Heard anything interesting?
Everyone's talking about you.
Heard anything interesting?
Uh-huh.
It's all true.
I've always found that truth is in the eye of the beholder.
Isn't that supposed to be "beauty"?
"Truth", "beauty"... works for a lot of things.
They say you never told anyone the truth about Galon Two. You didn't even defend yourself at the court martial.
What was to defend? I didn't follow orders. Eight members of the away team died.
Your fault.
My fault.
So you sit alone in crowded rooms staring at your drink.
You kind of enjoy it, don't you?
Enjoy it... ?
You go out of your way to torture yourself... You work so hard at it, you've gotta love it.
Who are you?
Guinan. I tend the bar. I listen.
You're not like any bartender I ever met.
You're not like any Starfleet officer I ever met. This might be the start of an interesting friendship.
I never stay anywhere long enough to make friends.
Too late. You just made one.
Bridge to Ensign Ro.
Go ahead.
Subspace communication coming in for you, Ensign.
Thank you.
Computer, direct subspace transmission to monitor...
Your report, Ensign.
Everything's going exactly as you predicted, Admiral...
Any indications of weapons or vessels beneath the surface?
The composition of the moon's crust is blocking the sensors...
... which is very likely why they chose this moon for their base of operations...
We're on a timetable here. Where's Ro?
Captain Picard to Ensign Ro.
Computer, locate Ensign Ro.
Ensign Ro is not on board the Enterprise.
Check the transport log.
(pressing a panel, reacts) She beamed down almost six hours ago, sir...
Mister Collins, any activity at the designated site of our meeting...
No, sir. They didn't show up...
What the hell is going on...
Prepare to transport us to the same location Ensign Ro beamed to... Mister Worf, phasers...
The tricorder is picking up molecular displacement traces... it suggests movement through this area during the last ten hours...
See if we can determine their direction... Standard search pattern...
Maintain tricorder security link.
Data, I'm picking up energy fluctuations over here... Troi to Picard. Captain, acknowledge...
Data to Picard... Data to Worf...
Captain Picard... I am Orta. Please excuse my appearance. Unfortunately, as a guest of the Cardassians some years ago, my face... was mutilated... my vocal cords cut.
Abducting us was not necessary.
I'm sorry. But after speaking with Ro Laren, I decided that it was.
Then she has done us both a disservice. For I am committed to peace.
I am not at all interested in peace. And I am not convinced you are, either.
Captain, I did not come here to undermine the mission...
Ensign, whatever your motives, you have already done enough damage to these negotiations. With your permission, Orta, I will have her transported back to my ship.
I came here to convince these people to listen to you... I didn't want this to end in bloodshed...
(losing patience, to Orta) There will be no bloodshed...
You don't know all the facts, Sir.
Perhaps you could share them with me.
Ro Laren is attempting to protect the interests of two worlds, Captain. She finds herself uncomfortably caught between them.
If you wish her to remain, I will agree, but she is not helping matters by fostering distrust between us...
I believe her concerns are justified.
I can assure you....
All is not what it seems to be, Captain. Perhaps someone is using you to get to me... perhaps you are a victim of this deception as well, I do not know.
Deception?
Your mission was to seek out the Barjoran terrorists who destroyed the Federation settlement on Solarion Four...
Yes...
As I have informed Ro Laren -- it was not the Bajorans.
... he admits responsibility for dozens of attacks on Cardassian targets. Why should we believe him about Solarion Four?
He has no reason to lie.
He fears our reprisal.
I didn't perceive fear or deception from him.
If they did not attack Solarion Four, who did? And why would anyone want to falsely implicate the Bajorans?
Perhaps someone wanted to draw us into this conflict...
But what would anyone have to gain by that... ?
Ensign. May I see you in my ready room?
Yessir.
You do not leave this ship without authorization.
Captain, I'm sorry, but...
This is not a discussion. You're restricted to your quarters for the remainder of the mission.
Dismissed.
What?
Heard you'd been grounded.
I really don't feel like talking right now.
Sure you do.
How come every time I tell you something you tell me I really mean the exact opposite?
You're one of those people who's got their poles reversed... you take a little unscrambling, but I've had a lot of practice.
So what do you feel like talking about?
Nothing you can help me with.
Never know until you try.
I got myself into this. I'm just trying to figure a way out. That's all. (meaningful beat, softer) Without anyone getting killed this time.
Seems like everybody's always just pulling my strings... that I've got no control.
For people like you and me... who lose our homes... that's how life feels sometimes...
You?
My people lost their homeworld too.
I'm in trouble.
There's more going on here than anyone on this ship knows... it's more than I know how to deal with. And I don't know who to trust...
Including yourself.
Especially myself.
I was in serious trouble once. More than I could handle alone.
What kind of trouble?
Not important now. Not yet. What is important is that I'd still be caught up in it to this day... if I hadn't trusted one man...
Come.
Ensign Ro has some things to talk to you about.
Ensign Ro has been confined to her quarters.
She can go right back to her quarters when she's done.
Guinan, I don't know why you are involved in this, but...
She's my friend.
I have found that Guinan is very selective about whom she calls a friend. Sit down.
Sir, when I'm finished telling you what I have to tell you... I'm probably gonna wind up back in the stockade. And if that's how it has to be... I just can't do this anymore.
What is it you can't do anymore, Ensign?
Admiral Kennelly came to me in prison... told me he'd arrange to get me out if I'd accept a mission...
That part I know.
Nossir. Not this mission. One for him and only him. You were being sent to talk, to negotiate... the Admiral knew that was hopeless... My job was to give Orta an incentive...
What kind of incentive... ?

One that you couldn't offer. That Starfleet couldn't offer. Orta was to end the terrorism against the Federation. Return with his people to the camps. In return he would get... Weapons. Ships. Things that could really make a difference against the Cardassians in the future.
I find that... almost impossible to believe. To suggest that Admiral Kennelly would consider sending weapons to terrorists...
If you ask him, he will deny it. But it's true. I didn't leave the ship without authorization... I received it last night from the Admiral.
You have been in contact with Admiral Kennelly during this mission?
Yessir. The subspace log can confirm that part of it at least.
Arming these people would be a violation of all that the Federation stands for. You cannot be blind to that...
Nossir. I'm not. But this was something... I had to do. When I was seven years old...

I was given a piece of sugar candy and led by a Cardassian into a room. My father was sitting inside. And he looked at me with eyes I'd never seen... And then the Cardassian began to ask him questions... and during the next two hours as I was forced to watch, my father was tortured until he died. I remember feeling so... ashamed... as my father begged for mercy... I was ashamed of him for being so weak. I was ashamed of being Bajoran. Later I began to understand how misguided those feelings were. And yet somehow they have remained a part of me. I do not want to be ashamed of my heritage any longer. I serve the Federation. But I am Bajoran. A Starfleet admiral presented me with an opportunity to help my people in their fight against the Cardassians. I had to accept it.
Have you made this offer to Orta?
No. After he told me the Bajorans had not attacked Solarion Four... nothing made sense anymore. I decided to wait until I could figure out what was going on...
That was a wise choice, Ensign. It probably saved you from another court martial.
Have you briefed Admiral Kennelly since our return from the surface?
Nossir. Captain, I don't know who to trust anymore...
Then why did you come to me?
That strange bartender of yours... She has a way of getting to you, you know? She said you were her friend.
It seems we find ourselves with... something in common. Do you think Orta would cooperate with us to determine the truth here?
I think I can persuade him.
Good. Our orders were to find him, bring him back to the camps... any way we could... perhaps that is exactly what we should do.
And then what?
And then watch what happens.
Captain's log, supplemental. I have become convinced that we are somehow involved in a conspiracy. I am hopeful the purpose behind it will be revealed in the next few hours.
Well done, Captain.
It was a team effort, Admiral. Ensign Ro proved invaluable.
Good. What's the next step?
The Enterprise will escort a Bajoran Antares-class carrier to the Valo Three camp at oh-five hundred hours... Orta and his people will be aboard.
Keep us advised of your progress.
Acknowledged. How's that Cardassian virus, Admiral?
A little better, thanks.
Good. We will report as soon as our mission is accomplished. Picard out.
Ensign Ro, take us to the designated coordinates...
Aye, sir.
Mister Data...
Yes, Captain?
Keep an eye on the Cardassian border, will you?
Aye, sir.
The Bajoran vessel is moving up from the surface, Captain.
On screen.
Hail them, Mister Worf...
Audio channel open... the ship has no visual capabilities.
This is Captain Picard, we are prepared to escort you to Valo Three...
Acknowledged, Captain. Be advised that our ship is limited to half impulse...
Ensign Ro, set a course for Valo Three... half impulse.
Aye, sir.
Engage.
I am monitoring increased activity inside Cardassian space... two ships are moving along the border... heading one-four-two mark zero-five-one...
Mister Worf, can you identify the class of these ships?
Cardassian warships... Galor class, type three...
Top of the line...
They are moving into a course parallel to our own, Captain.
Yellow alert. Continue to monitor them...
Ensign Ro, what's the closest we get to the Cardassian border on the current heading to Valo Three?
Thirteen thousand, four hundred kilometers, sir.
E-T-A?
Eight minutes.
That's where it will be.
The Cardassian ships are changing course... they are crossing the border...
They're increasing power to forward weapon grids...
Red alert.
Ensign Ro... change course to intercept the Cardassians... open channel to the Bajoran vessels...
Open.
This is the Enterprise. We are moving to intercept two Cardassian warships... maintain your present course and speed.
Acknowledged, Enterprise.
Cardassians are in visual range.
On screen.
We are being hailed by the Cardassians...
Open a channel, Mister Worf.
I am Jean-Luc Picard of the Federation Starship Enterprise... how can I help you?
Gul Dolak, Cardassian Militia Four One. We have no argument with you, Captain...
I'm pleased to hear that, Gul Dolak, for all of us in the Federation value the peaceful relations with our Cardassian neighbors.
No more than we value the relations with our Federation neighbors.
Good. Now that we've established our mutual good will... what's on your mind?
We have identified the Bajoran ship you are escorting as a terrorist carrier...
Terrorist carrier... are you certain?
Most certain, Captain. It has committed many crimes against us... we know its markings well...
Well, rest assured, there will be no terrorist attacks today. We are escorting these Bajoran settlers to the camp on Valor Three. You may monitor their course if you wish.
We would request that you withdraw... and leave the matter to us.
This is neutral space, Gul Dolak. You have no jurisdiction here.
Nor do you.
If we withdraw, what do you intend to do to the Bajoran vessel?
We intend to destroy it.
I see. Well, that puts me in a difficult position. I've promised to escort these people to their camps.
You are protecting the enemies of the Cardassian people... if you do not withdraw, we will take great offense...
I'm sorry to offend you, Gul Dolak. But I cannot withdraw.
We are prepared to take any steps necessary.
Is that intended as a threat?
It is a complaint. From your Cardassian neighbors. You have one hour to withdraw. Dolak out.
Advise Starfleet of our status, Mister Data. When Admiral Kennelly calls, I'll speak to him in my ready room.
It seemed, Admiral, that they knew our course, our destination, our plan...
I'm sure they monitor the border at all times for terrorist activity... their sensors just picked up Orta's ship, that's all...
I'm not convinced of that...
The important thing is, what do we do now?
Any suggestions, Admiral?
You have to protect the Cardassian peace, that's our top priority.
Sir, I see no way to protect the Cardassian peace without sacrificing the Bajorans.
If that's your call, I'll support it.
No. I'm not willing to give them up.
You're not looking at the big picture, Jean-Luc... we can't afford to lose the Cardassian treaty...

Well, I just see a different big picture, Admiral... it looks something like this... I see the Cardassian liaison, with his Cardassian virus, coming to meet with you after the attack on Solarion Four. Now, we have a mutual enemy, he says. The Bajoran terrorists. The Cardassians can't find them. But maybe the Federation can. I am beginning to see that our mission has been, in fact, to expose Orta... so the Cardassians could move in and destroy him.
I think you've lost your perspective, Captain. We'll discuss it further when you return. For now, I'm giving you a direct order to withdraw. Kennelly out.
Ensign Ro, set a course, bearing one-eight-seven mark one-zero-two... one quarter impulse.
Aye, sir.
He ordered us to withdraw?
The Cardassians are moving toward the Bajoran vessel, Captain.
Hold present course.
The Bajoran ship has been destroyed.
Subspace transmission coming from Starfleet, Captain. Admiral Kennelly.
On screen.
It is on a secure channel. Perhaps in your ready room, Captain?
No. Here. On screen.
Report.
The Cardassians have destroyed the Bajoran ship.
All hands lost... ?
No, sir.
Survivors?
No, sir. No one was on board.
What are you talking about?
The ship was controlled from the ground. Communications were handled through a subspace relay aboard the vessel.
This was your idea, Picard?
Actually, no... this was Ensign Ro's idea... but I fully endorsed it. I suspected that something like this might occur.
They're terrorists, dammit. Why the hell would you want to protect them?
I am more concerned with protecting the honor and integrity of Starfleet.
Do you know how many of our people they killed on Solarion Four?
The Bajorans did not attack Solarion Four.
Is that what Orta told you?
Yes.
And you believed him?
Admiral, Orta's ships are old and obsolete. They do not have warp capabilities. They could not have reached another star system... let alone attack one.
But then who was responsible?
I would suggest you ask your friend the Cardassian liaison, Admiral. The only explanation I can think of is that the Cardassians staged it.
The Cardassians. Why?
Perhaps they were hoping to find someone in Starfleet like you, Admiral, who would be foolish enough to solve their Bajoran problem for them.
What will happen to him?
I'm not sure. A hearing, definitely. Perhaps a court martial.
If he's sent to the stockade on Jaros Two, tell him to request a room in the east wing... the west wing gets awfully hot in the afternoon. How soon do you intend to return to Lya Station Alpha, sir?
A few weeks. We have some surveying to do in sector two-one-three-oh-five.
Then, perhaps I should arrange for other transportation back.
Ensign, you were recruited for one mission and if you wish to be relieved of further duty, I will approve it. But I'd like you to consider remaining in Starfleet.
You're not serious.
It would be a shame for Starfleet to lose someone with your potential.
Thank you. But this uniform... it just doesn't fit, Captain... and you know it.
That can change.
I don't think so.
I've observed a certain quality about you that... might be harnessed, molded...
... don't count on it...
There's still a lot you can learn from Starfleet, Ensign.
I've always thought Starfleet could learn a lot from me, Captain.
That is an attitude I have found to be common among the best officers I've served with. You are not one of those officers, Ensign, but you might be someday... if you decide to work at it.
An interesting challenge, sir. And I rarely refuse an interesting challenge. There would be one condition.
Condition... ?
Picard to Enterprise. Two to beam up.
Captain's log, stardate 45614.6. We have been contacted by an androgynous race called the J'naii to investigate the disappearance of a shuttlecraft.
We are approaching the designated coordinates, Captain.
On screen.
Long-range scan, Mister Data.
Sensors find no evidence of the shuttle anywhere within the star system.
It couldn't have travelled outside the system.
Mister Data, reconfigure for a high-resolution sweep with a radius of one million kilometers. Look for possible debris.
Scan shows no debris within that radius.
I don't understand it. A shuttle doesn't simply vanish.
There has to be an explanation...
Captain, I am detecting an unusual reading... It appears to be a neutrino emission with no visible source.
Explanation?
I have none. I recommend we launch a probe.
Make it so.
The probe is launched.
The probe is transmitting information within normal parameters. Sensors do not show evidence of any unusual phenomenon --
The probe is no longer transmitting.
What happened? Where did it go?

Captain's log, supplemental. The sudden disappearance of our probe suggests that we may have found the first instance of what is called null space -- an anomaly which until now had been only theoretical. Commander Riker has been working around the clock with a team of J'naii specialists to formalize this hypothesis.
During the creation of a star system, when clouds of interstellar dust and gas coalesce... turbulent regions of magnetic and gravitational fields may develop.
If certain conditions occur, these fields can condense into abnormal pockets of space.
We think your system contains one of these null pockets.
If we're right, this pocket would absorb electromagnetic energy from anything that entered it...
Like a shuttlecraft.
Or a probe. Making them powerless.
But outside the pocket, all energy is bent around it -- making it naturally cloaked. That's why we can't see it, and sensors don't read it.
Is the shuttle still there?
We think so. The ship probably couldn't sustain its power... but other than that it wouldn't be damaged.
Since our shuttles carry plestorene-based backup systems, we think life support would sustain for as long as ten days.
Then perhaps our crew has survived...

We can send one of our shuttles into the null space -- but its energy output would be absorbed as well. Our chief engineer is working on a way to maintain the power reserves long enough to rescue your crew.
Commander... we're grateful for your help. Whatever resources we can provide are yours.
I've been thinking... when the time comes, I'd like to pilot the shuttle.
It's a Starfleet craft...
I can't ask you to put yourself in danger to rescue our crew.
You can't pilot a shuttle you're not familiar with.
I happen to be a good pilot...
I happen to be a good pilot, too. I also know my way around Starfleet shuttles. So... what if we team up?
When can we go over your shuttle flight operations?
Right now.
It's a short-range craft... with two twelve-hundred fifty millicochrane warp engines...
Looks like microfusion thrusters...
Right.
Armament?
Usually none. But it's been fitted with two type-four phaser emitters... we'll use them to chart the null space.
Chart it?
Commander La Forge wants to get an idea of how big this pocket is. He thinks the rate of energy absorption will be linked to its size.
I'm not sure how we go about mapping something we can't see...
That's where the emitters come in. We'll shoot a series of photon pulses into the pocket and chart the points where they disappear. We should be able to plot a fairly complete outline that way.
Let's take a look at the controls.
Maybe later we can try a flight simulation, but first let's do a systems review. I'll walk you through it...
Propulsion system... transfer conduits... where's the schematic of the reactor assembly? Oh, there it is... engine nacelles...
There's nothing here that's unfamiliar.
Navigational deflector... redundant graviton polarity source generators...
You're handling those controls like you grew up in a shuttle...
I did. My parents were pilots. I started flying with them before I could walk. And as soon as I was old enough, I entered flight school. Krite was my instructor.
He had a good student.
"He?" Commander, there are no "he's" or "she's" in a species without gender.
Okay. For two days I've been trying to construct sentences without personal pronouns. I give up... what should I say? "It?" To us, that's almost rude.
We use a pronoun which is neutral. But it doesn't really have a translation.
Then I'll just have to muddle through... so be tolerant if a stray "he" or "she" slips by, okay?
Well, if that's the systems review, I don't see any problems here. What's next?
Lunch.
What is it?
Split pea soup. My father's recipe. I had it programmed into the replicators.
Well?
Unusual... but I think I like it...
It's very healthy. Helps keep you warm on a cold Alaskan night.
We prefer to stay warm by sleeping with a friend.
I see...
Not to mate... just to sleep together. For warmth.
Sounds better than pea soup.
We are puzzling to you, aren't we?
A little. It's hard to grasp the idea of having no gender...
It's just as hard for us to understand the strange division you have in your species... males and females.
You... are male.
Tell me... about males. What is it that makes you different from females?
Snips and snails and puppy dog's tails...
You have a dog's tail?
That's an old nursery rhyme. Girls are made of sugar and spice. Boys are made of snips and snails...
That makes it sound better to be female.

It's an old fashioned way of looking at the sexes. Not to say that there aren't real differences. Physically, men tend to be bigger... stronger in the upper body. We have different sexual organs. Men don't bear young...
What about... feelings? Emotional attitudes? Are they different?
Well... most people think so. But that's the kind of question that might take an hour or two to answer.
Let me ask you... What's it like... on a planet where the people have no gender?
I'm afraid I don't understand.
Well... who leads when you dance? If you dance...
We do... and... whoever's taller leads.
Without the "battle of the sexes"... you probably don't have as many arguments...
Just because we don't have gender doesn't mean we don't have conflict. We're very strong- minded... we love a good fight.
Sounds like there aren't that many differences between your species and mine...
Maybe not.
What kind of woman do you find attractive?
I like a woman who's intelligent and sure of herself... somebody I can talk to and get something back. But the most important thing of all -- she has to laugh at my jokes.
And is that the kind of woman all human males prefer?
Not at all. Some men like quiet, demure women... others prefer a lot of energy... some respond only to physical attractiveness... others couldn't care less. There aren't any rules.
You make it sound very complex.
Believe me -- it is.
Perhaps it is that complexity... which makes differences in the sexes... so interesting.
Good evening, Commander.
Good evening.
Please take my place, Krite. I have to be going.
Thank you for going over the flight protocols, Commander. It's been very helpful.
Captain's log, stardate 45616.3. Commander Riker and the J'naii pilot have set out on a mission to chart the null space pocket. If they are successful, we can then proceed with a rescue attempt.
I've illuminated the delta-four grid map. We can start there and then expand.
Stand by forward phaser array...
The pulse vanished at delta four-point-two by point three.
Firing second burst...
Delta four-point-four by point five.
It's working. I think we'll be able to give Commander La Forge the information he needs.
Delta four-point-five by point seven...
I'm initiating computer task hand-off...
Commander... tell me about your sexual organs.
Ahhh...
Is that an uncomfortable subject for Humans?
No... but it doesn't tend to be a topic of casual conversation...
I'm interested in your mating practices... what is involved when there are two sexes.
Correcting course... zero-two-one mark zero...
Mating.
Right. Well, it's pretty simple. The men inseminate the women and the women carry the babies.
Our fetuses are incubated in fibrous husks which both parents inseminate. From what we know of other species, our method is less risky and less painful.
And less enjoyable...
Less enjoyable?
For Humans... the sexual act brings a closeness... an intimacy... it's a very pleasurable experience... (beat: on the other hand) Inseminating a husk...
That's just the last step. Mating is a long ritual for us... full of variety and invention... I assure you -- it's extremely pleasurable.
I'm picking up a neutrino emission... from within the null space.
That may be coming from our shuttle. I'll note these coordinates.
I wonder...
What... ?
If a Human and a J'naii would be sexually compatible...
I don't know...
Of course, it would never be permitted.
Why not?

The idea of gender... it's offensive to my people. You see, long ago we had two sexes, as you do. But we evolved... into a higher form. I don't mean to sound insulting... but on my planet we've been taught that gender is... (struggling for the least offensive word) ...primitive.
Primitive.
Less evolved...
Maybe so. But sometimes there's a lot to be said for an experience that's... primitive.
Delta-five grid is fully plotted...
Adjusting course... zero-two-nine mark zero.
The port engine is down...
Reducing power in the starboard nacelle...
That's not enough... I have to activate the maneuvering thrusters to correct the spin...
Thrusters aren't responding...
I'll try to reroute the firing sequence...
Inertial dampers are failing... hang on!
Enterprise to shuttle... do you read me?
Affirmative... we've lost an engine...
We'll try to get a tractor beam on you...
The sooner the better...
Enterprise, we have an injury. Transport Soren directly to sickbay.
Right away, Commander.
It's just a mild concussion... You're going to be fine. This will reduce the inflammation.
Doctor... you are female.
Yes...
Forgive me... I don't mean to be rude... but I'm curious. What is it like?
Well... it's... just the way I am. I've never thought about what it's like.
What is it that makes you female?

Very specific biological factors. Females carry two X chromosomes, males carry an X and a Y. Hormone levels are distinctly different; males produce primarily testosterone, while women produce estrogen. Our sexual organs are very different -- females' are geared to bearing and nursing the young.
I've noticed... that you tend to have longer hair... you arrange it more elaborately... and you apply color to your bodies.
Color... ?
You put color on your mouths... your eyes... your cheeks... even your fingernails. The men don't.
That's true...
Why do you decorate yourselves like that?
It's a long-time custom... we're used to it... ... but I think the real reason -- is to attract men.
Really?
Mmmm-hmmmm...
Then... it's up to women to attract the men?
Oh, believe me, men want to be attractive, too -- but they go about it differently.
No color...
No color. They'd rather pretend they're not doing anything to attract a woman... even when it's the most important thing on their minds.
It's very confusing. Are women considered superior? Or are men?
Neither. In the past, women were often considered weak and inferior. But that hasn't been true for a long time.
Do you... enjoy being a woman?
Yes. As a matter of fact, I enjoy it a lot.
Will... your co-pilot is fine. The injury was minor.
I'm glad to hear it.
I'm afraid you're not rid of me yet, Commander. I'll be able to complete the mission.
Then you should hear my new regulation: no more gymnastics in the shuttlecraft.
I'm glad you're all right...
What happened... why did the shuttle go into a spin?
Apparently, the port engine nacelle nicked one of the protrusions from the null pocket, and shut down.
Are we still on schedule for the rescue attempt?
That depends on how you're doing.
I'm fine. We should check out the port engine --
Whoa... let's get the doctor's opinion first...
Doctor... ?
I don't see a problem. But if you have any symptoms... headache, dizziness -- come back.
You have my word.
All right... this round, the game is -- Federation Day.
What is that?
The Federation was founded in Twenty-one-sixty-one. So twos, sixes, and aces are wild.
That is a woman's game.
Oh? Why is that?
All those wild cards... they support a weak hand. A man's game has no wild cards.
Let me get this straight. Are you saying it's a woman's game because -- because women are weak and need more help?
Yes.
And just this afternoon I was insisting to one of the J'naii that those attitudes were nothing but a distant memory.
The J'naii...
They bother me.
Why, Worf?
They just do.
They are all alike. No males. No females.
I'm sure we're just as strange to them.
Well, one of them seems to be overcoming the differences... at least with regard to one of us...
What are you saying, Doctor?
I could be wrong... but I get the definite impression that Soren... is attracted to Commander Riker.
A human and a J'naii? Impossible.
Why?
Good question. Worf?
With all the wild cards, it is difficult to know exactly what is in my hand. However, I will open with... fifty.
The port engine nacelle functions are fully restored... maneuvering thrusters are operational...

The portable transporter array is in. Once we get into null space, we'll have to initialize it before we transport the J'naii crew to this shuttle. But there should still be enough power left to beam all of us back to the Enterprise.
Is the buffer field generator installed?
Not yet. Geordi figures it'll be ready to go at oh-eight-hundred hours tomorrow. We should adjust the engine balance before that. Can you access the starboard thrust manifold?
There...
Okay, calibrate it to arc at six-point-three while I optimize the plasma flow.
Commander...
Mmmmm?
I'd like... to tell you something. Something that's not easy to say.
What's that?
I... find you attractive.
I'm taking a terrible risk, telling you that. It means... revealing something to you... Something that, if it were known on my planet, would be very dangerous for me.

Occasionally, among my people, a few are born who are -- different. Who are throwbacks to the era when we all had gender. Some are born with strong inclinations toward maleness... and some have urges to be female. I am one of the latter.
I have to admit... I got the feeling you were different.
I was hoping you would. But in front of Krite and the others, I must be careful not to reveal myself.
Why?

On our world these feelings are forbidden. Those who are discovered are shamed and ridiculed. Only by undergoing psychotectic therapy and having all elements of gender eliminated can they become accepted into society again.
Those of us who have these urges... live secret, guarded lives.
We seek each other out... always hiding, always terrified of being discovered...
How long have you known you were like this?
I've known I was different all my life. But I didn't understand how or why until I was older.
And when you realized... what then?

I remember when I was very young... before I understood what I was... there was a rumor in my school that one of the students preferred a gender... in that case, male. The children started making fun of him... every day, they got more cruel... They could tell he was afraid... and that seemed to encourage them. He appeared in class one morning, bleeding... his clothes ripped. He said he'd fallen down.
Of course the school authorities heard about it... They took him away and gave him psychotectic treatments.
When he came back... he stood in front of the whole school and told us how happy he was now that he had been cured.
After that... I knew how dangerous it was to be different. And as I got older, and realized what I was, I was terrified. I've lived with that fear ever since.
Do you have... relationships... with others?
Yes -- with those who have discovered they are male.
I've had to live a life of pretense and lies. With you... I can be honest.
Don't say anything. Just... think about it.
Okay, Commander, everything checks out. The energy buffer is installed and functioning. I estimate it should reduce the power drain to your systems by about forty percent.
Any guess how long we'll have?
Let just say... you don't want to waste any time once you get in there.
You'll have to give him continuous readouts on energy consumption. I can't even predict if the drain will be at a constant rate.
I understand.
Then... that's it.
I'll monitor you as far as I can, Commander. But once you get into that pocket -- you're on your own.
Since we don't know the condition of the shuttle crew, I'll beam us all directly to sickbay.
I'll notify Doctor Crusher to be standing by.
La Forge to bridge...
Picard here...
We're ready to initiate shuttle prelaunch sequence.
Proceed, Mister Data.
Prelaunch sequence is underway.
Request flight clearance.
Clearance is granted. The shuttle is underway.
Good hunting, Commander.
Thank you, sir. See you for dinner.
Heading three-five-five mark zero-one-two.
Heading confirmed.
Energy readings are normal, with power reserves stabilized at one hundred percent.
Acknowledged.
It's dead ahead, approximately fifty kilometers.
Riker to Enterprise. We're going in.
Riker to Enterprise... Riker to Enterprise...
Power reserves are down to eighty-four percent.
Look...
Try hailing them...
Calling the "Taris Murn... " Do you read me?
I'm getting sensor readings. They're unconscious -- but they're alive. Stand by. I'm going to transport them over here.
Power reserves at sixty-eight percent and dropping.
The null space must be affecting the annular confinement beam...
We used ten megajoules with that attempt. We're down to thirty-four percent of reserves.
We can give it one more try. More than that and we won't have enough power to get ourselves out of here.
They need medical attention quickly.
Okay. Stand by to transport to the Enterprise.
Here we go...
Energy consumption?
We're down to nine percent. Will, we don't have enough to get back.
If we just sit here, we'll lose all our systems within an hour -- including life support.
I'm rerouting the propulsion system to the transporter... Rechannel the navigation systems...
Let's transfer every microjoule of energy we've got... sensors... life support... this might give us one last shot.
An energy shift of that size... it'll overload the phase compensators... the shuttle --
Will explode. But if we stay here we're dead, anyway.
Maximum energy levels in five seconds...
See you in a minute.
Doctor... ?
They've been oxygen-deprived... but I don't think there's any significant damage. Prepare some dexalin.
Commander -- thank you.
Your colleague Soren was a great help.
Captain... if you would all join us this evening... we would like to express our gratitude...
We'd be happy to.
Noor will be eager to get a first-hand report. We should return to the surface.
I will see you tonight then, Commander?
There you are, Commander. I wondered what had happened to our guest of honor.
Just getting some fresh air. I can take so much of these social functions... then I need to breathe a little.
I would think you had attended so many affairs like this it would be second nature to you.
I was raised in the outdoors. I'm never that comfortable in crowded rooms...
What do you think of our planet? Isn't it beautiful?
Yes. Quite beautiful.
We have many varieties of plant life... (gesturing into the woods) Perhaps you would like to inspect some of them.
Yes, I would. I've always been interested in exobotany.
Please. Let me take you on a tour.
Thank you. It's very kind of you.
One of my favorites is this menellen tree. The leaves first turn pure white, and then blue when the weather gets cold...
This is called a falla bush... it produces a fragrant flower on only one day of the year...
Captain's log, stardate 45620.4. We remain in orbit of J'naii, charting the null pocket. We hope that a detailed map of the anomaly will prevent the loss of other ships.
Come in.
Hello, Will.
What's all this?
Wonderful things... my mother sent me a box that belonged to one of my father's ancestors. It had been stored on Earth years ago and just recently turned up.
Do you know who these people are?
No. A few of the pictures are marked with names... but most of them aren't. I look at all these faces... and wonder who they are... if they might be related to me...
This one looks like you...
Deanna... I've got something on my mind... and I had to see you...
Has something happened?
I've met someone... someone who's becoming important to me...
Soren...
Yes.
You're my friend... so it seemed like... I'm not sure. It just seemed right to tell you.
I'm glad you did.
Nothing will change between us, will it?
Of course it will. All relationships are constantly changing.
But we will always be friends. Maybe even better friends. You're part of my life, and I'm part of yours. That much will always be true.
Turns out the null pocket is even more irregular than we expected, Commander.
Maybe its configuration is shifting.
I don't think so... the measurements you took are holding. It just has more projections than we thought. It's going to take longer than we planned to get it mapped.
I'm headed for the shuttle bay. We're fitting another shuttle to help in the survey.
Have you made plans for dinner this evening?
I have some paperwork to do... I thought I'd start on it...
I'd like to discuss some of our suggestions for regulating travel around the null space. Maybe we could have an early dinner... so you could still get your work done afterwards.
I'd like that.
Nineteen hundred hours?
That would be fine.
Hello. I'm here to see Soren...
I know.
We had an appointment. To discuss plans for regulating the --
I don't think so, Commander.
Excuse me?
We know about the two of you. We know what you're doing.
Where's Soren?
And we're going to make sure it doesn't happen again.
Answer me -- where is Soren?
Gone. In custody. And there's nothing you can do about it.
The hell there isn't.
You are aware of the charges against you?
Yes.
Do you intend to dispute them?
Well? What is your response?
Are you in charge here?
Commander Riker -- these proceedings are closed to anyone but --
I think I just opened them.
Sir, this is a private matter. We are grateful for your recent help, but that gives you no right to interfere with our personal concerns --

I want you to know what really happened. It's all my fault. I was attracted to Soren. I pursued... I insisted. I didn't understand your ways until Soren told me. And rejected me. Nothing happened between us.
I ask your forgiveness. I behaved... inappropriately.
Is this true?
No.
Soren --
I am tired of lies.
I am female. I was born that way. I have had those feelings... those longings... all my life.

It is not unnatural. I am not sick because I feel this way. I do not need to be helped, and I do not need to be cured. What I do need -- what all of those like me need -- is your understanding and your compassion.
We do not injure you in any way. And yet we are scorned, and attacked. And all because we are different.

What we do is no different from what you do. We talk and laugh... we complain about work and we wonder about growing old... we talk about our families, and we worry about the future... We cry with each other when things seem hopeless. All the loving things that you do with each other... that's what we do. And for that, we are called misfits, and deviants... and criminals.
What right do you have to punish us? What right do you have to change us? What makes you think you can dictate how people love each other?
I congratulate you, Soren. Your decision to admit your perversion makes it much more likely that we can help you.
No, wait... you don't have to do this...
Commander?
Let me take her away. She can come with me, we'll give her asylum on the Enterprise. You'll never have to see her again.
That would solve the problem, wouldn't it? You'd be rid of her... she couldn't influence anyone else...
Commander, after Soren's diatribe, you must think we are a cruel, repressive people. Nothing could be further from the truth.
I'm just trying to find a solution that would satisfy everyone --
In fact, we are a remarkably free and open society. Our people have rights and liberties which give them a great deal of self-determination. We are, by all measurements, an enlightened race.
Then how is it... that Soren has no choice about her sexual orientation?
We are concerned about our citizens. We take our obligations to them seriously. Soren is sick... and sick people need to get well.
Did it ever occur to you she might prefer to stay the way she is?

You don't understand. We have a very high success rate in treating deviants like this. And without exception -- they have become happier people after their treatment. And grateful... that we care enough to cure them.
You see, Commander... on this world, everyone wants to be normal.
She is --
Take her to quarters. Treatment will begin tomorrow.
Don't do this --
Soren --
No more, Commander.
Enterprise. One to transport.
I can't just leave her there. They'll give her these psychotectic treatments... I don't know what to do.
I could talk to Noor. Perhaps there's a way to work this out --
Sir, their minds are set. They don't want to hear another solution.
Then I'm not sure there's much we can do.
There has to be.
My relationship with Soren isn't trivial... she's very important to me.
It's my fault this has happened. And I have to help her.
Will, if you've come here for sanction... to take matters into your own hands... I can't give it to you.
I know that, sir. But I know I have to do something.
Interfering in the internal matters of the J'naii is prohibited by the Prime Directive...
I'm aware of that.
If you violate it, you may be putting your career in jeopardy.
Starfleet doesn't take these matters lightly... and I can't defend you if you go too far... Do you understand that?
You've made yourself very clear, sir.
Will... don't risk everything you've worked for...
Thank you, sir. May I be excused now?
Who is it?
Lieutenant Worf.
Come in.
Commander, I have the plan for deploying warning buoys around the null space.
Fine. Just leave it, I'll look at it later.
Yes, sir.
Thank you. You're dismissed.
Commander... I am aware of what transpired on the planet's surface...
Are you by any chance considering an... unannounced visit?
I will go with you.
Lieutenant --
Sir... you are my commanding officer... and if you order me to stay on board, I will obey. But I ask you not to give that order. A warrior does not let a friend face danger alone.
I suggest we change clothing first.
The meeting is ending. I think they will bring her out of the building soon.
Okay. They'll probably come down that path... we can take cover there -- -- behind those rocks.
Yes, Commander.
She'll be under guard... no telling how many...
I will handle the guards. You take her to cover.
Something's happening...
They're leaving.
Could you excuse us? I have to talk to her...
Wait...
Don't worry... we'll be out of here in a minute...
Will, please...
We're almost there...
You can't do this...
I won't let them hurt you. You'll be safe on the Enterprise.
Soren...
I'm so sorry... it's my fault you got involved in all this...
It's going to be all right... everything's going to be fine...
No, it's not.
What are you talking about?
It was all a mistake. I should have realized it from the beginning...
What... ?
That I was sick. I had these terrible urges... that's why I reached out to you... but it was wrong. I see that now.
(a little shake of her head) I don't understand how I could have done... what I did.
Maybe... maybe Doctor Crusher could treat you... bring you back... to the way you were before.
Why would I want that?
Soren... I love you.
I'm sorry.
How long to the Phelan system?
At warp six, fifty-three hours, sir.
Commander... ?
Captain.
Starfleet has just sent a message asking us to proceed to the Phelan system to negotiate a trade agreement.
Yes, sir.
I wasn't sure when to tell them we'd be underway. Is our business with the J'naii finished?
Finished, sir.
Very well. Ensign, take us out of orbit, set a course for the Phelan system. Warp six. Engage.

Captain's log, stardate 45470.1. The Enterprise has been diverted to the Moab sector to track a stellar core fragment of a disintegrated neutron star. Our science teams have been asked to monitor the planetary disruptions it may cause.
We've got a problem... our core fragment is going to pass by Moab Four in six days...
Isn't that what we anticipated?
We didn't anticipate that somebody would be living there.
An artificial environment has been constructed on the southern continent, sir.
Have you definitely established someone's inside it?
Yes, Captain. Sensors are reading Human lifeforms.
Human.
Has there been a response to our hails, Mister Worf?
Negative, Commander.
Any starships ever reported missing in this sector, Data?
Nossir.
How the hell did they get themselves on a deserted planet?
I'm pretty sure they know we're here...
Mister La Forge?
I'm picking up deep E-M readings... looks like wave emissions from an obsolete subspace relay...
Which would suggest they also have the ability to communicate with us.
Mister Worf, open the lower band frequencies that were most commonly used in the last century...
Channel open.
This is Captain Jean-Luc Picard of the Federation Starship Enterprise. It is urgent that you respond.
Sir, defensive shields around the structure are increasing strength.
Not exactly a welcome mat.
We mean you no harm. We must warn you that your planet is about to experience massive seismic disruptions due to an approaching stellar core fragment. No structure will be able to withstand them.
They are responding.
On screen.
Enterprise... I am Aaron Conor...
Mister Conor, we were unaware of any Human colony in this system.
Captain, I don't want to be rude but we don't wish to interact with outsiders. I have only responded because of your warning.
The fragment will begin to have serious effects on your planet in six days.
Yes, I know. We have been tracking it. But our biosphere has been constructed to withstand quakes of eight-point-seven on the Richter Scale.
Mister Data... ?

The fragment has a density of one hundred billion kilograms per cubic centimeter. As a result, when it passes Moab Four, it will cause tectonic shifts well beyond eight-point-seven on the Richter Scale.
I'm afraid we're going to have to evacuate your people.
Evacuate? That's not possible. There must be an alternative...
The alternative, sir, is dying...
Mister Conor, if you wish, we will find you another isolated planet that is safe.
No, we must remain here.
Maybe we haven't made ourselves clear...
Of course, you have, Commander... and I hope I've made myself clear that we must seek an alternative solution...
We will gladly explore the possibility with you, Mister Conor... would you care to come aboard to discuss it?
Our environment is sealed. No one can get in or out.
We are capable of matter/energy transport...
Matter/energy?
We can take you directly through the structure.
Really. That's quite remarkable.
May we arrange for your transport?
No. I must stay here.
But under the circumstances, I will permit a small delegation from your ship inside the biosphere... ... if only to see this matter/energy transportation you speak of...
Very good. Commander Riker and an away team will join you shortly. Picard out.
Limit the away team to three people, Will...
Geordi -- I want to overwhelm him with evidence...
Understood.
Counselor, I'd like you with us on this one...
This is a mistake.
Good Lord, Martin, what would you have me do?
Anything that would keep them out of here.
We have nothing to hide.
We have a great deal to lose.
What is that... ?
It's them... Look at this, Martin...
Incredible.
Hello. Forgive me... I'm not sure how to welcome you. You are the first visitors we've ever had...
It's lovely... I can understand why you are reluctant to leave, Mister Conor...
We are not just "reluctant", Ms. Troi. It is imperative that we remain.
It would be suicide to evacuate. It would destroy everything we've worked for two centuries to accomplish...
You see, this is an engineered society...
Engineered... ?
Genetically engineered...
Our ancestors came from Earth to develop the perfect society. They believed that through controlled procreation, they could create people without flaws... and those people would build a paradise.
